post: How does second-hand shops here survive the rent prices?

comment.body:
I think you should go talk to some shopowners. Its a very specific business, and its hard to guess. 

Also I don't think you need to be on a good shoppingstreet, you cater to a specific clientele, they will come find you as long as you pop up on Google maps and do some advertising, especially if you do a niche. 

Have you thought about starting on one of the many loppemarked to get a feel of the market.

Most are charities, but for the commercial ones my guess is that they have very low rent, because they've been there since rents were less unfair or they've been lucky and gotten low rent in a co-op because it's been difficult to rent out the space.

Some of the housing associations have implemented internal laws that they have to lease out x anount of the living area, and sometimes they cannot ajust the rent without changing the rules thus making it more expensive for everyone - hence some shops are allowed to rent for much cheaper than the market price

This is the way. There are also sometimes more biz models than you might realize. Eg renting clothes for media or specific events, repairs, and other kinds of consulting. Doing a small thing like Solar suggests will give you a glimpse into the process and viability.
